content.body: In the HTML spec, in https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-source-element (4.8.2 The `source` element), in the first Note, the phrase "react to changes in the environment" is a link to https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#img-environment-changes. However, if you follow the link and click on "react to changes in the environment", the popup doesn't list the occurrence in 4.8.2.
content.formatted_body: In the HTML spec, in https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-source-element (4.8.2 The source element), in the first Note, the phrase "react to changes in the environment" is a link to https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#img-environment-changes. However, if you follow the link and click on "react to changes in the environment", the popup doesn't list the occurrence in 4.8.2.

content.body: This is presumably because the 4.8.2 occurrence is an `<a href>` rather than a `<span data-x>`. Is that intentional?
content.formatted_body: This is presumably because the 4.8.2 occurrence is an <a href> rather than a <span data-x>. Is that intentional?

content.body: zcorpan: You added the 4.8.2 `<a href>` in 9e9a6730 about 2.5 years ago.
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: You added the 4.8.2 <a href> in 9e9a6730 about 2.5 years ago.

content.body: Similarly, in 4.8.5 "The iframe element", at https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#:~:text=Furthermore%2c%20notice , "optional start and end tags" uses an `<a href>` to link to https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#syntax-tag-omission, whose popup doesn't link back to 4.8.5.
content.formatted_body: Similarly, in 4.8.5 "The iframe element", at https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#:~:text=Furthermore%2c%20notice , "optional start and end tags" uses an <a href> to link to https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#syntax-tag-omission, whose popup doesn't link back to 4.8.5.

content.body: That one goes back to 2013, before `data-x`, so I think maybe it evaded conversion to `<span data-x>` when that came along.
content.formatted_body: That one goes back to 2013, before data-x, so I think maybe it evaded conversion to <span data-x> when that came along.

content.body: I think those are the only two such cases.
Wondering if I should submit a fix for them.
Luke Warlow: we had agreement that form pseudo-elements would not expose underlying API details right so ::picker(select):popover-open would not work?
content.formatted_body: Luke Warlow: we had agreement that form pseudo-elements would not expose underlying API details right so ::picker(select):popover-open would not work?

content.body: I'm seeing WPT tests for the opposite. Working on a correction now.
Hmm it might be worth checking GitHub for usage? But yeah :open:picker(select) does the same job so should be fine.
* Hmm it might be worth checking GitHub for usage? But yeah :open::picker(select) does the same job so should be fine.

m.new_content.body: Hmm it might be worth checking GitHub for usage? But yeah :open::picker(select) does the same job so should be fine.

content.body:
The picker stuff might have pre-dated that discussion.

Also I think currently the fact it's popover is exposed in other ways?

The fact it closes other popovers for example. See Keith's recent issue on that.

Personally I think it's probably harmless but there's an alternative so I think it's also fine to drop it.
I'm pretty sure I said this from the when we proposed ::picker so I'm rather annoyed.
I haven't really made up my mind what would be best for Keith's issue. I do think we want consistency between native and base appearance as ultimately that should just be (mostly) appearance.

Isn't this (the picker being a popover) something well defined though? The implementation has to use a popover else there will be differences? It's not something that affects appearance:auto too?

I can't remember the discussions when picker originally came up unfortunately.

I suspect usage is low and it's changeable. Is this something specified one way or another? I guess it might just be a consequence of picker being a popover? I can't speak for whether chromium will want to change it but I'm fine with it from a css forms perspective.

> <@lwarlow:igalia.com> Hmm it might be worth checking GitHub for usage? But yeah :open::picker(select) does the same job so should be fine.

Thinking about it most of the time the styles don't need to apply to the picker conditionally because it's only shown when open so usage is probably even lower. Perhaps it's used for some animations or something. Do the tests shine a light on the intention?
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @lwarlow:igalia.com
Hmm it might be worth checking GitHub for usage? But yeah :open::picker(select) does the same job so should be fine.
Thinking about it most of the time the styles don't need to apply to the picker conditionally because it's only shown when open so usage is probably even lower. Perhaps it's used for some animations or something. Do the tests shine a light on the intention?

content.body: It's a popover, but what pseudo-classes a pseudo-element exposes is a separate matter.

For animations maybe? I'm going to change `html/semantics/forms/the-select-element/customizable-select/select-picker-animations.html` and `html/semantics/forms/the-select-element/customizable-select/switch-picker-appearance.html`. Will put up a PR shortly.
content.formatted_body: For animations maybe? I'm going to change html/semantics/forms/the-select-element/customizable-select/select-picker-animations.html and html/semantics/forms/the-select-element/customizable-select/switch-picker-appearance.html. Will put up a PR shortly.

content.body: jmdyck: I don't recall why I used `<a href>`, it's clearly inconsistent with the other note that has a normal xref
content.formatted_body: jmdyck: I don't recall why I used <a href>, it's clearly inconsistent with the other note that has a normal xref

content.body: PR mentioned above: https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/57739

If you create a cross-origin iframe whose `name=foo` via the iframe attr, then `window.foo` should be undefined, right? That's my reading of https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#document-tree-child-navigable-target-name-property-set. I'm asking because it seems no browser follows this; all let you reference the child Window via `window.foo`
content.formatted_body: If you create a cross-origin iframe whose name=foo via the iframe attr, then window.foo should be undefined, right? That's my reading of https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#document-tree-child-navigable-target-name-property-set. I'm asking because it seems no browser follows this; all let you reference the child Window via window.foo

content.body: Hey, I'm not sure why the pr-preview isn't working for https://github.com/whatwg/webidl/pull/1568
I thought it was because the bikeshed build was failing, but I fixed that and it's still not working
Dominic Farolino: I wonder if that regressed with the navigable refactor. name=foo should work. The cross-origin frame setting window.name="foo" is what should remain hidden.
content.formatted_body: Dominic Farolino: I wonder if that regressed with the navigable refactor. name=foo should work. The cross-origin frame setting window.name="foo" is what should remain hidden.

content.body: annevk: Just to be clear, by "name=foo should work" do you mean `<iframe name=foo src=x-origin>` should let the parent reference the child via `window.foo`?
content.formatted_body: annevk: Just to be clear, by "name=foo should work" do you mean <iframe name=foo src=x-origin> should let the parent reference the child via window.foo?

content.body: I agree we should change the spec to match browsers on this one.
Dominic Farolino: yup, you can always address cross-origin iframes, you should just not be able to obtain information from them (though we are bad at that too of course)
content.formatted_body: Dominic Farolino: yup, you can always address cross-origin iframes, you should just not be able to obtain information from them (though we are bad at that too of course)

content.body: annevk: is https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/12071 ok now?
